tn.text: "if the Israelites do not believe"
"pick it up by the tail" or "grasp it by the tail"
"turned into a rod" or "changed into a staff"

tn.ref: the God of their ancestors, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob
tn.text: Abraham, Isaac and Jacob were three of their ancestors. They all worshiped the same God.
This word is used to create an exclamation, showing surprise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])

The word "as" here is used to compare what Moses' hand looked like. Leprosy causes the skin to look white. You may not have a word for snow in your language. If so, consider an alternative that describes something white. AT: "as white as wool or as white as the sand on the beach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"acknowledge" or "accept"
"an excellent speaker"

tn.ref: I am slow of speech and slow of tongue
tn.text: The phrases "slow of speech" and "slow of tongue" mean basically the same thing. Moses uses them to emphasize that he is not a good speaker. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here "tongue" refers to Moses' ability to speak. AT: "unable to speak well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Who is it who made man's mouth?
tn.text: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the Creator who makes if possible for people to speak. AT: "I Yahweh am the one who created the human mouth and the ability to speak!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Who makes a man mute or deaf or seeing or blind?
tn.text: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the one who decides if people can speak and hear, and if they can see. AT: "I Yahweh make people able to speak, or hear, or to see, or to be blind!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he alone makes these decisions. AT: "I, Yahweh, am the one who does this!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I will be with your mouth
tn.text: Here "mouth" refers to Moses' ability to speak. AT: "I will give you the ability to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he will be glad in his heart
tn.text: Here "heart" refers to inner thoughts and emotions. AT: "he will be very happy" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: put the words to say into his mouth
tn.text: Words here are spoken of as if they were something that can be physically placed in a person's mouth. Here "words" refers to the message. AT: "give him the message that he is to repeat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: I will be with your mouth
tn.text: The word "mouth" here represents Moses choice of words. AT: "I will give you the right words to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "mouth" here represents Aaron's choice of words. AT: "I will give him the right words to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "mouth" here represents Aaron repeating what Moses told him. AT: "He will say what you tell him to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you will be to him like me, God
tn.text: The word "like" here means Moses would represent the same authority to Aaron as God did to Moses. AT: "you will speak to Aaron with the same authority with which I spoke to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
in-law** - This refers to the father of Moses' wife.

Here "heart" refers to Pharaoh. His stubborn attitude is spoken of as if his heart was hard. AT: "will cause Pharaoh to be stubborn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "Israel" here represents all the people of Israel. AT: "The people of Israel are my own children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the people of Israel are spoken of as if they were a firstborn son who causes joy and pride. AT: "is like my own firstborn son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you have refused to let him go
tn.text: The word "him" refers to the people of Israel as God's son. AT: "you have refused to let my son go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will certainly kill your son, your firstborn
tn.text: The word "son" here refers to the actual son of Pharaoh.

tn.ref: Yahweh met Moses and tried to kill him
tn.text: This may have been because Moses had not circumcised his son.
This is the name of Moses's wife. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This was a knife with a sharpened stone blade.
It is possible that the word "feet" here may have been a more respectful way to refer to the genital area of the body. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: you are a bridegroom to me by blood
tn.text: The meaning of this metaphor is unclear. It was probably a known saying in that culture. AT: "you are related to me by this blood" or "you are my husband because of blood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
You may want to add a word that marks the beginning of a new part of the story, as the UDB does.
This may have been the mountain at Sinai, but the text does not include that information.

tn.ref: he had sent him to say
tn.text: The word "he" refers to Yahweh, and "him" refers to Moses.

tn.ref: in the sight of the people
tn.text: "before the people" or "in the presence of the people"
"saw the Israelites" or "was concerned about the Israelites"
Possible meanings are 1) "they bowed their heads in awe" or 2) "they bowed down low in reverence." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
